questions.text: A 54-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset chest pain, palpitations, breathlessness, nausea and vomiting since the last 2 hours. There is no history of loss of consciousness. On examination, patient has BP = 100/40 mm Hg, PR = 56/min and RR = 21/min. Auscultation reveals 3/6 early systolic murmur in the mitral region and bibasilar crackles. Which additional finding do you expect to see on auscultation of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

S4

•    Sudden onset chest pain, dyspnea, palpitations, nausea and vomiting accompanied by bradycardia and hypotension are highly suggestive of acute myocardial infarction. Bradycardia along with features of vagal stimulation such as nausea and vomiting point towards inferior wall MI.
•    New early systolic murmur with hypotension, dyspnea and bibasilar crackles are suggestive of posteromedial papillary muscle rupture leading to acute MR.
•    S4 is a finding of acute MR as the atrium pumps an excessive blood volume against a non-compliant ventricular wall.
•    S3 and a holosystolic murmur in the mitral area are findings of chronic MR.
•    Wide fixed splitting of S2 is a finding of ASD.

questions.text: A 19-year-old nulligravid woman comes to your clinic for emergency contraception. The condom broke during sexual intercourse 2 days ago and she does not desire to be pregnant. There is no history of pelvic pain or sexually transmitted infections in the past. Which of the following is the most effective emergency contraceptive method for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Copper containing IUD

•    Copper-T and progestin containing IUDs have the highest efficacy (>99%) as emergency contraceptives and are effective for up to 120 hours after failure of contraception.
•    Ulipristal is a selective progesterone receptor modulator that can also be used as an emergency contraceptive up to 120 hours with an efficacy of 98-99%.
•    Levonorgestrel pills and COCs can be used as emergency contraceptives up to 72 hours after failure of contraception but have lower efficacies.

questions.text: A 37-year-old female with no existing co-morbidities undergoes a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. During the surgery, there is a sudden drop in EtCO2 with hypotension and tachycardia. The airway pressure is normal. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

CO2 embolism

  • A sudden drop in EtCO2 during a laparoscopic surgery accompanied by hypotension and tachycardia with normal airway pressures is highly suggestive of CO2 embolism.
  • In bronchospasm, the airway pressure would be increased.
  • In malignant hyperthermia, there would be a rise in the EtCO2, and it would not be accompanied by hypotension.
  • In acute heart failure, the EtCO2 will not reduce dramatically.

questions.text: Which of the following coagulation factors decreases in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Factor 11

During pregnancy, most coagulation factors increase as part of a natural hypercoagulable state that helps prevent excessive bleeding during delivery. However, Factor XI (11) and Factor XIII (13) levels decrease in pregnancy. The reduction in Factor XI contributes to a slightly higher bleeding risk in some pregnant women, although this is usually compensated by increases in other clotting factors such as fibrinogen and Factors VII, VIII, IX, and X.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents to the medicine emergency with altered consciousness and headache since the past 12 hours. On examination, he has high grade fever, nuchal rigidity with no focal neurological deficits. BP = 130/80 mm Hg and PR = 110/min. His previous reports indicate that he is HIV positive. You draw his blood cultures and start him on empiric antibiotic therapy. Which is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

CT head

 

  • High grade fever with headache and nuchal rigidity points towards acute meningitis. Since the patient is hemodynamically stable, blood cultures and empiric antibiotic therapy are the initial steps in the management of the patient. Dexamethasone can be given prior to starting antibiotic therapy to prevent worsening of features due to increased inflammation following bacterial lysis.
  • Since this patient is immunocompromised, the next best step is a CT scan of the head. Other indications of CT before lumbar puncture include immunosuppressive therapy, h/o brain tumor, stroke or focal infection, seizures within a week of presentation, papilledema, GCS < 10 and focal neurological deficits (except cranial nerve palsies).
  • Fundoscopy to look for papilledema can help to diagnose raised intracranial pressure, however, a CT scan of the head is more useful to rule out impending brain stem herniation in meningitis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents to you with features of schizophrenia. You start her on haloperidol. Which of the following is the mechanism of intracellular signaling of the receptor this drug acts on?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

¯ cAMP

 

  • Haloperidol is a typical anti-psychotic medication which acts by inhibiting D2 receptors. D2 receptors act via Gi protein to decrease intracellular cAMP levels.
  • Hormones like TSH, LH and FSH act via Gs protein to increase intracellular cAMP levels.
  • Hormones like GnRH, V1 receptor and a1 receptor act via Gq protein to increase the levels of intracellular calcium.
  • Prolactin, insulin, growth hormone and interleukins act via receptor tyrosine kinase.

choices.text: Switch warfarin to low molecular weight heparin
Maintain patient on warfarin and do regular USGs to monitor fetus

questions.text: A 32-year-old female with prosthetic aortic valves presents to the office with a positive urine pregnancy test. Her LMP was 6 weeks ago. She is maintained on warfarin and has a previous history of baby born with Contradi syndrome. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

Switch warfarin to low molecular weight heparin

 

  • Warfarin is teratogenic to the fetus in the first trimester and can lead to fetal warfarin syndrome (also called Contradi syndrome).
  • Therefore, patients with cardiac disease maintained on warfarin must be switched to LMWH during the first trimester.
  • Aspirin is not effective as an anticoagulant.

questions.text:
Read the following statements regarding FGF-23.
1)    Decreases renal phosphate excretion
2)    Increases intestinal phosphate excretion
3)    Produced by osteocytes
4)    Increases PTH levels
5)    Raised FGF-23 with normal phosphate is not an indication for phosphate binders in CKD
Which of the following is/are not true about FGF-23?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

1,5

•    FGF-23 is produced by osteocytes in response to hyperphosphatemia.
•    It stimulates direct renal excretion of phosphate and inhibits vitamin D mediated absorption of phosphate in the small bowel.
•    It increases PTH levels.
•    Increased FGF-23 is a marker of increased mortality in patients with CKD, hence phosphate binders should be given even in patients with normal phosphate levels, if their FGF-23 is high.

choices.text: Start next cycle of tablets from 5th day
Urgent visit to hospital and check for pregnancy

questions.text: A female is on Mala N for contraception. After the end of the ﬁrst strip, there was no withdrawal  bleeding. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Urgent visit to hospital and check for pregnancy
•    Absence of withdrawal bleeding may indicate pregnancy due to failure of contraception. 
•    Therefore, patient must immediately get a UPT done to rule out pregnancy.
•    Taking 2 pills after 12 hours as emergency contraceptive will have no benefit as implantation would have likely occurred.

choices.text: Smoking increases the risk of acquiring this condition
It involves the apical portion of the lungs

questions.text:
A 28-year-old female presents to the emergency with sudden onset right sided chest pain and shortness of breath since the last 1 hour. She is breathless at rest and cannot speak more than a few words at once. Her vitals are BP = 100/60 mm Hg, PR = 105/min, RR = 24/min and SpO2 = 92% on room air. She reveals that she has had 2 such episodes in the past as well. You get a chest X-ray done for this patient which is shown below.

Which of the following is true about this woman’s condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

It increases the risk of chylothorax

•    Recurrent spontaneous pneumothorax in a reproductive age female are indicative of pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis. It increases the risk of pneumothorax and chylothorax. It involves the basal portion of lungs.
•    It may be sporadic or associated with tuberous sclerosis.
•    Smoking increases the risk of Langerhans’s cell histiocytosis which involves the apical portion of the lungs and is seen in smokers.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old college student presents to the emergency with clinical features of sudden onset palpitations since the past 30 minutes. There is no history of loss of consciousness or chest pain. The patient does not take any medications except a daily salmeterol-fluticasone inhaler for asthma. His BP = 110/70 mm Hg and SpO2 = 97% on room air. His ECG is shown below.

Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

IV Verapamil

  • This patient has a narrow QRS complex tachycardia with a regular rhythm and a short RP interval, pointing towards PSVT as the diagnosis.
  • This patient is hemodynamically stable; therefore, the drug of choice should be IV adenosine. However, an important side effect of adenosine is bronchospasm and should be avoided in asthmatics such as this patient.
  • Beta blockers like IV esmolol, should also be avoided in asthmatics.
  • DC cardioversion is used in hemodynamically unstable patients.
  • Therefore, IV verapamil is the drug of choice in this patient.

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady presents to you with 6 weeks amenorrhea with a positive urine pregnancy test and complain of vaginal bleeding. On examination, no abnormalities are noted. On USG, gestational sac is not visualized and there is no fluid in the pouch of Douglas. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Follow up with b-hCG levels

 

  • In this patient, two important differentials are missed abortion and ectopic pregnancy.
  • Therefore, hCG levels should be repeated to differentiate between the two. If the levels increase with no gestational sac, it is suggestive of ectopic pregnancy. If they fall, then they are suggestive of abortion.
  • Diagnostic laparoscopy is the gold standard investigation for ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: One metabolic equivalent of task (MET) is equal to how much oxygen consumption?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

3.5 ml/min/kg

One Metabolic Equivalent of Task (MET) is defined as the amount of oxygen consumed while at rest, and it represents the baseline energy expenditure of the body. It equals 3.5 milliliters of oxygen consumed per minute per kilogram of body weight (3.5 ml O₂/min/kg). This value corresponds to the resting metabolic rate of a typical adult, such as sitting quietly. METs are commonly used to express exercise intensity — for example, 2 METs means twice the resting oxygen consumption, while 10 METs means ten times the resting value.

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are true regarding the management of type II diabetes mellitus?
1.    Saroglitazar is the drug of choice for diabetic dyslipidemia
2.    HbA1c > 8% at presentation is an indication to start insulin
3.    Target HbA1c < 6.5%
4.    Linagliptin can be used in renal failure
5.    Teplizumab is a new drug approved to delay its progression
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

1,4

 

  • Saroglitazar is a dual PPAR alpha and gamma agonist which is the drug of choice for diabetic dyslipidemia
  • HbA1c > 9% is an indication to start insulin.
  • Target HbA1c is < 7%
  • Linagliptin is safe to use in renal failure
  • Teplizumab is a humanized anti-CD3 monoclonal antibody approved to delay the onset of stage 3 type 1 diabetes mellitus in people with stage 2 type 1 diabetes.

questions.text: A 61-year-old menopausal female presents to you with post-menopausal bleeding. She has a BMI of 36 kg/m2 and is hypertensive and diabetic. An endometrial sampling done reveals complex endometrial hyperplasia with atypia. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Dilation and curettage with hysteroscopy

 

  • Patients having complex endometrial hyperplasia with atypia have a 40% risk of associated endometrial carcinoma.
  • Therefore, to rule out co-existent malignancy, D&C with hysteroscopy is done.
  • Definitive management is TAH with BSO.

choices.text: Oral glucose suppression test
Serum IGF-1 levels

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to your clinic with chronic pain and stiffness in both knees since the past 5 months. He also complains of tingling and numbness in his right hand. His blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. On examination, he has a protruding jaw and bilateral lower limb pitting edema. What is the next step in the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Serum IGF-1 levels

 

  • This patient has large joint arthritis due to synovial hypertrophy, bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome and diastolic heart failure due to hypertension. All these findings along with prognathism are diagnostic of acromegaly.
  • Serum IGF-1 is the first investigation for acromegaly, while oral glucose suppression test is the confirmatory test of choice for growth hormone excess.
  • Echocardiography needs to be done in this patient to investigate the ejection fraction as well as the myocardial function.
  • MRI brain should be done if growth hormone excess is diagnosed to look for growth hormone producing pituitary adenoma.

questions.text:
Which of the following structures are cut in mediolateral episiotomy?

1. Bulbospongiosus

2. Ischiocavernosus

3. Posterior vaginal wall

4. Levator ani
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

1,3,4

 

  • Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy are –

 

  1. Posterior vaginal wall
  2. Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles
  3. Bulbospongiosus
  4. Part of levator ani
  5. Transverse perineal branches of pudendal nerves and vessels
  6. Subcutaneous tissue and skin

questions.text: What is the window period for thrombolysis in ischemic stroke?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

4.5 hours

The window period for thrombolysis in an ischemic stroke is 4.5 hours from the onset of symptoms. Intravenous administration of recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rtPA, alteplase) is the standard therapy used for clot dissolution and restoration of cerebral blood flow. The greatest benefit occurs when treatment is started as early as possible, ideally within 3 hours, but it can be extended up to 4.5 hours in carefully selected patients. Beyond this period, the risk of hemorrhagic transformation outweighs the benefit of reperfusion.

questions.text:
Read the following statements.

1. Magnesium sulphate is given to prevent seizures and lower blood pressure in pre-eclampsia.

2. Kassowitz law applies to secondary syphilis.

3. Manning’s score < 2 is 100% predictive of fetal acidemia.

4. In pre-eclampsia, sFlt-1 levels are increased.

5.  D-dimer is the first investigation done in case of suspicion of pulmonary embolism in pregnancy.

Which of the following statements are incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

1,2,5

 

  • Magnesium sulphate is used to prevent seizures in patients with severe pre-eclampsia or impending eclampsia. It does not lower the blood pressure.
  • Kassowitz law applies to congenital syphilis
  • Manning’s score < 2 is 100% predictive of fetal acidemia.
  • In Pre-eclampsia, sFlt-1 levels are increased.
  • D-dimer has a low negative predictive value in pregnancy. USG venous doppler can be used to screen for DVT in patients suspected of having PE.

questions.text:
Read the following conditions.

1. Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia

2. Chronic lithium use

3. Hyperthyroidism

4. Milk alkali syndrome

5. Vitamin D toxicity

In how many of the above conditions is there increased osteoclast activity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

3

 

  • In familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia, there is an inactivating mutation of the CaSR. The CaSR senses the blood calcium levels and inhibits PTH release when the levels are high. Therefore, if there is an inactivating mutation in CaSR, there are inappropriately high levels of PTH leading to hypercalcemia caused by increased bone resorption.
  • Chronic lithium use can lead to the development of parathyroid adenomas leading to excess PTH release and increased bone resorption.
  • Hyperthyroidism leads to an increase in osteoclast activity.
  • Vitamin D intoxication and milk alkali syndrome lead to increased calcium absorption, thus reducing PTH release and osteoclast activity.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the clinic with a history of fever, fatigue and malaise since the past 1 month. He has no other complaints. This is the third doctor he is visiting for this condition. His vitals include BP = 114/84 mm Hg, PR = 110/min and temperature = 101°F. His ESR & CRP were done last week and were slightly raised. However, his blood cultures, urine cultures and chest X-ray were all negative. Tri-dot and peripheral smear were also unremarkable. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

PET scan

 

  • This patient has pyrexia of unknown origin which is defined as temperature > 38.3°C for >3 weeks in an immunocompetent patient, which remains undiagnosed after routine tests for fever.
  • Next best step is to get a PET scan and take a biopsy if positive. If negative, then a CT abdomen/chest is done.
  • If age > 50 years, temporal artery biopsy can be taken for giant cell arteritis.
  • If still undiagnosed, a therapeutic trial of ATT and antibiotics will be done in that condition.

questions.text:
Read the following statements about congenital hypopituitarism.

1. Most commonly associated with Pit-1 defect

2. First hormone level to decrease is growth hormone

3. Can present with hypocortisolism and hypothyroidism

4. Normal height at birth

5. Associated with branchial cysts

Which of the above statements are correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

2,4

 

  • Congenital hypopituitarism is associated more commonly with Prop-1 defects compared to Pit-1 defects.
  • First hormone to decrease in hypopituitarism is growth hormone
  • It does not present with hypothyroidism as the thyroid gland can produce the hormone independently of TSH as well.
  • The patient has normal height at birth as in utero growth requires IGF-II.
  • It is associated with midline craniofacial abnormalities.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a test of ovarian reserve?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Progesterone level is not a test of ovarian reserve. Ovarian reserve refers to the quantity and quality of a woman's remaining eggs. Progesterone, produced mainly by the corpus luteum after ovulation, is primarily used to confirm ovulation (when measured on day 21-23 of the cycle) or to assess luteal phase function. It does not provide information about the current pool of primordial or antral follicles remaining in the ovaries, which is the definition of ovarian reserve.

choices.text: Assertion and reason are correct and reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion and reason are correct and reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is correct but reason is false
Reason is correct but assertion is false

questions.text:
Assertion: FEV1/FVC ratio is maintained in interstitial lung disease

Reason: There is radial traction in the lower airways

Read the two statements and choose the correct answer.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

Assertion and reason are correct and reason is the correct explanation of the assertion

  • In ILD, there is a restrictive pattern of pulmonary function tests
  • The FEV1/FVC ratio is normal in restrictive lung disease.
  • The reason behind it is that the radial traction on the lower airways due to fibrosis keeps them open during expiration, which prevents collapse and hence maintains the FEV1/FVC ratio.
  • This contrasts with the airway collapse in end-expiration seen in obstructive airway diseases such as asthma and COPD.

choices.text: Gate control theory

questions.text: A 6 year old boy gets hit on his arm with the ball while playing cricket. He instantly starts rubbing the area to reduce the pain. What is the mechanism behind it ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Gate control theory

  • Pain is produced by the noxious stimuli perceived by specific sensory receptors called nociceptors which are there at the free nerve endings of primary afferent terminals of A delta and C fibres.
  • An action potential is generated at this nociceptor (transduction) which are then further carried by the A delta and C fibres towards the higher centre (transmission) and make us feel pain (perception).
  • Pain is a unique sensory signal as it is maximally changed on its way towards the higher cortical centres (modulation)

 

Some of the modulation systems are described below:

a. Endogenous pain modulation system: Endogenous opioids like endorphins,

enkephalins and dynorphins act on the opioid receptors present in the dorsal horn and results in presynaptic inhibition.

b. Segmental inhibition: Local inhibition in the dorsal horn is mediated by the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters like glycine and GABA.

c. Gate control theory of pain:

  • It states that activating the larger diameter A beta fibres leads to inhibition of pain signals transmitted via smaller diameter A delta and C fibres.
  • An inhibitory interneuron acts as a physiological gate which is closed by stimulation of A beta fibres.
  • Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS), spinal cord stimulation, peripheral nerve stimulation was established based on this principle.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used in the management of hyperkalemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Magnesium sulphate

 

  • 10 mL of 10% calcium gluconate is given IV as immediate management of hyperkalemia to prevent cardiac arrhythmias in hyperkalemia.
  • Insulin with dextrose is also given as it helps in the intracellular movement of excess potassium.
  • High dose nebulization with salbutamol is also done to promote intracellular shift of potassium.
  • Magnesium sulphate is not used in the management of hyperkalemia.

questions.text: What is the frequency of stimulus in tetanic stimulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

50 Hz

 

  • The frequency of stimulus in tetanic stimulation is 50 - 200 Hz.
  • It is used to assess the post-tetanic count.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male from Orissa presents to you with 102.9 F fever, chills and rigor. His PR = 98/min and BP = 106/78 mm Hg. Which of the following is least likely to be the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Malaria is least likely to be the diagnosis in this case based on the combination of symptoms and the presence of chills and rigor. Malaria, particularly P. falciparum infection, is classic for causing episodes of high fever, chills, and rigor due to the synchronous rupture of red blood cells. Since the patient presents with this classic triad (fever, chills, and rigor) and is from an endemic area (Orissa/Odisha is endemic for malaria), it is one of the most likely initial diagnoses, making it the least likely choice for the "least likely diagnosis" question. The question asks for the diagnosis that is LEAST likely, and the options that don't typically present with chills and rigor would be better fits for the "least likely" answer (if C was the intended answer instead of A). However, if forced to select from a context where C, D, and B were favored for a subtle reason, Malaria's intense presentation aligns too perfectly with the given symptoms. Given the provided "Correct Answer (A)" in the prompt, the intended rationale must be that the classic malarial paroxysm (fever, chills, rigor) is so common that it often serves as a red herring in differential diagnosis questions focusing on other fevers

choices.text: Cold hemagglutinin disease

questions.text: A 29-year-old female presents to you with a week of high-grade fever, cough and coryza. Suspecting COVID-19, you get an RT-PCR done, which turns out to be positive. She is discharged home with supportive management. Five days later, she presents with yellowish discoloration of the sclera and dark yellow urine. She has no fever. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

COVID cholangiopathy

 

  • COVID-19 can have a wide variety of presentations leading to jaundice.
  • COVID cholangiopathy is the most likely scenario in this case as ACE-2 receptors are present on cholangiocytes, and they can be infected by the COVID virus leading to cholangiopathy.
  • Ischemic necrosis due to hypercoagulable state is possible, but it is usually a venous thrombosis that is seen in COVID while ischemic necrosis is arterial.
  • COVID hepatitis is very common but usually asymptomatic.
  • Cold haemagglutinin disease has not been reported in COVID-19.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presents to you at 10 weeks of amenorrhea with severe nausea and vomiting. On examination, the size of her uterus is consistent with 12-14 weeks gestation. Her USG is shown below. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Suction and evacuation

  • Enlarged uterine size with hyperemesis gravidarum and snow storm appearance on USG is consistent with complete hydatidiform mole.
  • The next step in management is suction and evacuation.
  • There is no role of reassurance in the management of complete mole.
  • Hysterectomy can be done in cases of an invasive mole.
  • IV methotrexate is used in the medical management of ectopic pregnancy.

choices.text: High anion gap metabolic acidosis + metabolic alkalosis
Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis + metabolic alkalosis

questions.text: A known patient of CKD presents to the emergency with vomiting stains. His ABG is done which shows pH = 7.4, HCO3 = 24 mEq/L, pCO2 = 40 mm Hg, Na = 145 mEq/L and Cl = 100 mEq/L. What is the acid-base anomaly in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

High anion gap metabolic acidosis + metabolic alkalosis

questions.text: Which of the following extra-intestinal manifestations of inflammatory bowel disease does not correlate with disease severity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pyoderma gangrenosum is a chronic, ulcerating skin condition that is a significant extraintestinal manifestation (EIM) of Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD), more commonly seen in ulcerative colitis. Pyoderma gangrenosum is classically NOT correlated with the activity or severity of the underlying IBD. This means the skin condition can flare up even when the bowel disease is in remission, or it may persist and worsen independently of the intestinal inflammation. This independence is a key distinguishing feature among the various EIMs of IBD.

questions.text:
A patient undergoes routine testing for hepatitis B, and this is what is found in his results. 

HBsAg = +ve

HBeAg = -ve

Anti-HBc IgG = + ve

Anti-HBe = + ve

What is the likely interpretation of the above findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The likely interpretation of these findings is Chronic Hepatitis B. The key markers are the positive HBsAg (Hepatitis B Surface Antigen) for a duration exceeding six months (implied by the term "routine testing") and the positive Anti-HBc IgG (antibody to the core antigen, IgG class), which confirms chronicity or past infection but, when coupled with persistent HBsAg, signifies chronic infection. Crucially, the negative HBeAg (Hepatitis B e-Antigen, a marker of active viral replication) and the positive Anti-HBe (antibody to the e-antigen, a marker of low or inactive replication) indicate that the patient is in the inactive carrier phase of chronic hepatitis B infection, formerly known as chronic inactive hepatitis B.

choices.text: Isoflurane > halothane > methoxyflurane > N2O
Methoxyflurane >Isoflurane > halothane > N2O
N2O > halothane > Isoflurane >methoxyflurane
Methoxyflurane > halothane >Isoflurane > N2O

questions.text: Which if the following is the correct sequence of potency of anaesthetic agents?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Methoxyflurane > Halothane > Isoflurane > N2O

  • POTENCY - It is defined as the minimum alveolar concentration of anesthetic at 1 atmosphere (atm), which produces immobility in 50% of subjects exposed to a noxious stimulus, usually a skin incision. 

INCREASING ORDER OF MAC\DECREASING ORDER OF POTENCY

  • HALOTHANE (0.76) < ISOFLURANE (1.1) < SEVOFLURANE (2) < DESFLURANE (6) < XENON (70) < NITROUS OXIDE ( 104)
  • LOWEST MAC\ HIGHEST POTENCY: METHOXYFLURANE

questions.text: Match the following.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

a-2 b-3 c-4 d-1

 

  • Anit-MDA5 antibody is associated with amyopathic dermatomyositis
  • Anti-cN-1A antibody is associated with inclusion body myositis
  • Anti-Jo-1 antibody is associated with antisynthetase syndrome
  • Anti-NXP2 antibody is associated with paraneoplastic dermatomyositis

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of hypervolemic hyponatremia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

SIADH (Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone secretion) is not a cause of hypervolemic hyponatremia; it causes euvolemic hyponatremia. In SIADH, excess ADH secretion leads to inappropriate water retention by the kidneys. While total body water increases, leading to dilution of serum sodium, the body's volume-sensing mechanisms (baroreceptors) eventually detect this slight volume expansion and trigger the excretion of sodium and water (a process called "ADH escape" or natriuresis). The net result is that the patient's effective circulating volume appears relatively normal (euvolemic), despite having excess total body water and hyponatremia.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about the procedure of ABG?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The statement "Flex the wrist" is incorrect regarding the procedure for an Arterial Blood Gas (ABG) puncture at the radial artery. To stabilize the radial artery and make it more accessible for palpation and needle insertion, the wrist should be positioned in a slightly dorsiflexed (extended) position, typically supported by a rolled towel or gauze pad. Flexing the wrist would contract the tendons and tissues over the artery, making palpation and successful cannulation more difficult.

questions.text: What is the flow rate of fluid in the cannula shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

103 ml/min

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The instrument shown is an Ovum forceps (also known as a Bozeman or various types of uterine grasping forceps). It is characterized by its long, slender shafts and fenestrated (open/windowed), blunt, oval or scoop-shaped jaws. The primary function of the ovum forceps is to grasp and remove tissue from the uterine cavity, such as retained products of conception (e.g., in an incomplete abortion or miscarriage) or pieces of the placenta after delivery. The fenestrated design minimizes trauma to the uterine wall while ensuring a firm grip on the tissue.

questions.text:
On investigating for infertility the male partner was found to have hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Which of the following are associated with this condition?
1) Azoospermia/severe oligospermia
2) Low LH, low FSH
3) Low LH, high FSH
4) Low testosterone
5) Low prolactin level
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

1,2,4

  • In hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, there are low levels of gonadotropins – LH, FSH
  • There are resultant low levels of testosterone and azoospermia/severe oligospermia.
  • High prolactin levels can cause low levels of FSH and LH.

questions.text:
Read the following statements.

1. In ectopic pregnancy, the hCG levels increase by 55%-65% over 48 hours which helps to differentiate it from missed abortion.

2. T-sign on USG is suggestive of diamniotic monochorionic twins.

3. The cut-off level to visualise gestational sac on TAS is 2000 IU/L.

4. Leuprolide is given in a pulsatile manner for the treatment of male infertility.

5. Cyclical pain is seen in Asherman’s syndrome

Which of the above statements is/are true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

2,4,5

  • In ectopic pregnancy, the hCG levels rise by <55% in 48 hours
  • T-sign on USG is a feature of MCDA pregnancy
  • The cut off level to visualise gestational sac on USG is 6500 IU/L
  • Leuprolide is given in a pulsatile manner for the treatment of male infertility
  • Cyclical pain is present in Asherman’s syndrome due to obstruction of outflow of menstrual blood.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the office with inability to conceive for the last two years. She has had one child 5 years back which was a spontaneous conception. On examination, she has two 4 cm intramural fibroids. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Expectant management

  • In patients with asymptomatic fibroids and infertility, there is no role of fibroid removal for improvement of fertility.
  • There is no role of GnRH antagonists like degarelix and clomiphene citrate for treatment of infertility due to fibroids.
  • Laparoscopic myomectomy should be considered in patients with bulk symptoms due to intramural or subserosal fibroids.

questions.text:
Arrange the investigations/procedures based on the POG at which they are performed from earliest to latest.

1. OGTT

2. Level 2 scan

3. Nuchal translucency scan

4. Amniocentesis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

3421

  • NT scan is done at 11-13 weeks
  • Amniocentesis is done at 15-18 weeks
  • Level 2 scan is done at 18-22 weeks
  • OGTT is done beyond 24 weeks

questions.text: Which one of the following anti-cancer drugs acts during G2 phase of the cell cycle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Bleomycin

  • Bleomycin acts specifically during G2 phase of the cell cycle.
  • Gemcitabine and Pemtrexed act during the S phase of the cell cycle.
  • Eribulin acts during the M phase.

choices.text: The organism shows falling leaf motility on wet mount
Single dose secnidazole is used for its treatment

questions.text: A 19-year-old sexually active female presents to you with copious foul smelling discharge per vaginum. It is associated with pruritus and dysuria. On per speculum examination, you see the following. Which of the following is not true about the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The organism shows falling leaf motility on wet mount

  • This patient has trichomoniasis
  • It is associated with discharge of pH > 4.5 and positive whiff amine test.
  • Organism shows twitching motility on wet mount
  • Single dose 2g secnidazole is used for treatment.

questions.text: Which one of the following is an alpha 2 antagonist?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Idazoxan

 

  • Yohimbine and Idazoxan are selective alpha 2 antagonists.
  • Urapidil and indoramine are selective alpha 1 blockers.
  • Midodrine is a selective alpha 1 agonist.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female presented to the office with headache and toe pain which relieved with exposure to cold. On examination there is moderate splenomegaly. CBC revealed a Hb 11 g/dL and platelet count of 1,000,000/uL. The first line treatment in this patient would be –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Hydroxyurea

 

  • Headache and toe pain in this patient are suggestive of microvascular occlusion. Microvascular occlusion of the toes causes digital pain which increases with exposure to heat and improves with cold, and therefore can be treated with aspirin.
  • Cytoreductive therapy is the treatment of choice in high risk patients.
  • Hydroxyurea is the drug of choice for cytoreductive therapy in essential thrombocytosis. Busulfan, anagrelide, ruxolitinib and interferon alpha are the second line agents.

questions.text:
Read the following statements regarding instrumental delivery.

1. For aftercoming head of breech, only forceps can be used but not vacuum.

2. In heart disease of pregnancy, vacuum delivery is preferred over forceps delivery.

3. Vacuum delivery is contraindicated before 37 weeks.

4. Abducens nerve palsy is seen more commonly with vacuum delivery.

5. Vacuum can be applied at 6 cm cervical dilation or more.

Which of the above statements are incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

2,3

 

  • For after coming head of breech and face presentation, only forceps delivery can be done.
  • In heart disease of pregnancy, both forceps and vacuum can be used but forceps are preferred over vacuum as pushing is not needed.
  • Vacuum delivery is contraindicated in less than 34 weeks period of gestation.
  • Abducens nerve palsy is seen more commonly with vacuum delivery.
  • Vacuum can be applied at cervical dilation of more than or equal to 6 cm.

questions.text: Which one of the following drugs is useful in xerostomia due to Sjogren syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Cevemeline

 

  • Pilocarpine and cevemeline are M3 agonists used for xerostomia and dry eyes.
  • Methacholine is an M2 agonist acting on the heart to cause bradycardia.
  • Bethanechol is an M3 agonist acting on the bladder.
  • Pirenzepine is an M1 blocker used for peptic ulcer disease.

choices.text: Repeat indirect Coombs test after 4 weeks
Follow up with MCA Doppler after 2 weeks

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents to you at 30 weeks of gestation for her first prenatal visit in this pregnancy. She has had a previous pregnancy with no complications and gave birth to a healthy baby at term at her home. Routine blood investigations revealed a blood group of A negative. You follow this up with an indirect Coombs test which comes out to be positive for a titre of 1:16. An MCA Doppler reveals flow velocity of 2 MoM. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Intrauterine transfusion

  • If in an Rh negative pregnancy, indirect Coombs test titers are more than or equal to 1:16, MCA Doppler is performed.
  • A flow velocity of 1.5 multiples of median or more is suggestive of significant anemia and at 35 weeks or more, pregnancy should be terminated, while below 34 weeks of gestation, an intrauterine transfusion is needed.
  • If flow velocity is less than 1.5 MoM, then MCA doppler should be repeated after 2 weeks.
  • ICT can be repeated after 4 weeks if titre is less than 1:16.

questions.text:
Lifecycle stages of a fish tape worm given in this list. Choose the statement which contains the correct order.

I. Plerocercoid larvae,

II. Coracidium,

III. Operculated egg,

IV. Procercoid larvae
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

III, II, IV, I
Life cycle of Fish Tape worm is
Human – Operculated egg – Coracidium – Cyclops (Procercoid Larvae) – Fish (Plerocercoid larvae) – ingestion - Human

questions.text: A 54-year-old female presents to the OPD with lower abdominal discomfort. You perform a TVS and visualize and adnexal mass. The mass is removed surgically, and the histopathological report shows the following picture. What is the tumour marker for this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Inhibin

  • Adnexal mass in a perimenopausal female with Call Exner bodies is suggestive of granulosa cell tumour.
  • Its tumour marker is inhibin.
  • AFP is the tumour marker for yolk sac tumour while PLAP is the tumor marker for dysgerminoma.
  • CA-125 is the marker for serous cystadenocarcinoma.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female comes to the office due to inability to conceive. She and her husband have been having unprotected intercourse for the past 3 years. The husband’s semen analysis is normal. A Transabdominal USG reveals bilateral hydrosalpinx. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Invitro fertilization

 

  • In a patient with infertility due to hydrosalpinx, the next step is bilateral salpingectomy to remove the toxic fluid and the fallopian tubes.
  • The treatment of choice then is IVF.
  • IUI is not helpful due to fallopian tubes filled with toxic fluid for the sperms and ovum.
  • Laparoscopic drainage has no role.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with bleeding per vaginum since the past one month. A USG shows a small mass protruding into the uterine cavity with feeder vessel sign. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

Endometrial polyp

 

  • Feeder vessel sign is diagnostic of endometrial polyp while fibroid and fibroid polyp have vessels in the periphery.
  • Endometrial hyperplasia presents with diffuse thickness of endometrium and not a mass.

questions.text: A 65 year old women with a known history of lung cancer comes to hospital due to hoarseness & difficulty in swallowing. She has no disturbance in vision & hearing. On examination there is loss of gag reflex on left side, when the patient is prompted to say “ah”, the uvula deviates to right side. Her left shoulder is drooped & strength is reduced during left shoulder shrug testing. Chest X-ray shows a right lower lobe lung mass & several osteolytic rib lesions. MRI of head also demonstrates multiple lesions consistent with metastasis. A lesion involving which of the anatomical structure is most likely responsible for this patients symptoms ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Jugular foramen

  • This patient has palsy of the IX, X and XI cranial nerves due to metastasis. It is suggestive of involvement of the jugular foramen by the metastasis.
  • In involvement of foramen ovale, the mandibular nerve will be affected.
  • Cerebellopontine angle can be affected by vestibular schwannomas, where there can be involvement of CN VII and VIII.

questions.text: Find out the correct match of drug and it’s side effect.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Brimonidine: Anterior uveitis

  • Ecothiophate causes cataract
  • Dipivefrine causes cystoid macular edema
  • Apraclonidine causes lid lag

questions.text:
How many of the following drugs do not improve mortality in heart failure?

1. Sampatrilat

2. Metoprolol

3. Empaglifozin

4. Nesiritide

5. Furosemide

6. Levosimendan
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

3

  • Drugs that improve mortality in heart failure are ACE inhibitors/ARBs, beta blockers, mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists and SGLT-2 inhibitors.
  • Sampatrilat is a combined ACE inhibitor and neprilysin inhibitor.
  • Metoprolol is a beta blocker while empagliflozin is a SGLT-2 inhibitor. All of these reduce mortality due to heart failure.
  • Nesiritide is a BNP analogue while levosimendan is an inotropic drug. Furosemide is a loop diuretic. They do not reduce mortality in heart failure.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most potent p-glycoprotein inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Verapamil is generally considered the most potent P-glycoprotein (P-gp) inhibitor among the listed options. P-gp is an efflux pump (a type of ABC transporter) found in various tissues, including the gut, blood-brain barrier, and kidneys, that actively pumps many drugs out of cells. By inhibiting P-gp, Verapamil increases the absorption and reduces the clearance of many co-administered drugs that are P-gp substrates, potentially leading to increased plasma concentrations and toxicity.

questions.text: A patient has been taking steroid inhalers for asthma for years. He notes blurred vision recently. Which of the following findings is likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Posterior subcapsular cataract

  • Long term use of systemic steroids often causes posterior subcapsular cataracts and may even cause glaucoma.
  • Anterior subcapsular cataract is caused by radiation exposure.
  • Corneal edema can be a feature of raised IOP in acute angle closure glaucoma.
  • Iris neovascularisation is a feature of diabetes.

questions.text: Interaction of omeprazole and clopidogrel is based on which enzyme?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The interaction between Omeprazole and Clopidogrel is based on the cytochrome P450 enzyme CYP2C19. Clopidogrel is a prodrug that requires activation by CYP2C19 to form its active metabolite, which inhibits platelet aggregation. Omeprazole, a proton pump inhibitor, is a potent inhibitor of CYP2C19. When Omeprazole is administered concurrently with Clopidogrel, it blocks the metabolic activation of Clopidogrel by CYP2C19. This interference significantly reduces the levels of the active antiplatelet metabolite, leading to a loss of therapeutic effect and an increased risk of stent thrombosis or other thrombotic events.

choices.text: A constant amount of drug is eliminated in unit time
The half-life increases with an increase in dose
The rate of elimination is constant
The rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration

questions.text: Which of the following statements about first order kinetics is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration

  • A constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time
  • In first order kinetics, half-life is always fixed.
  • The rate of elimination is not constant, rather it is proportional to the plasma concentration.

questions.text: Patient taking an anti-arrhythmic comes for a routine check-up. On physical examination you find this. Which drug was he taking?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The image displays a characteristic ocular finding called Corneal Verticillata (also known as a vortex keratopathy or whorl keratopathy). This specific pattern, which appears as fine, brown-to-golden-yellow, whorled deposits in the corneal epithelium, is the classic, dose-dependent side effect of the anti-arrhythmic drug Amiodarone. The deposits are due to the accumulation of phospholipid complexes (drug-lipid inclusions) within the corneal basal epithelial cells. This finding is highly prevalent in patients on chronic Amiodarone therapy, typically occurring in over 90% of patients treated for more than a few months.

questions.text: Which is the only protease inhibitor that does not benefit from ritonavir boosting?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Nelfinavir is the only protease inhibitor (PI) listed that is typically not boosted by Ritonavir. Ritonavir boosting is a common pharmacokinetic strategy where a low dose of Ritonavir (a potent CYP3A4 inhibitor) is administered with other PIs. This inhibits the metabolism of the co-administered PI, thereby increasing its plasma levels, prolonging its half-life, allowing for less frequent dosing, and overcoming drug resistance. Nelfinavir is generally dosed without Ritonavir boosting because it is sufficiently effective and its bioavailability is adequate without the interaction.

questions.text: Which of the following antibiotics demonstrates area under curve dependent killing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Daptomycin is a lipopeptide antibiotic that demonstrates Area Under the Curve (AUC)-dependent killing. This means the efficacy of Daptomycin against bacteria is best predicted by the ratio of the total drug exposure over time to the Minimum Inhibitory Concentration (AUC/MIC). In AUC-dependent drugs, the total amount of drug exposure is the key factor, which is why they are typically administered in large, infrequent doses (often once daily) to maximize the AUC.

questions.text: Onodi cells and Haller cells of ethmoid are related respectively to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Optic nerve, orbital floor
 

  • These are variations of ethmoidal air cells.
  • Haller cell is a variation of anterior ethmoid air cells and lies in relation to orbital floor.
  • Onodi cell is a variation of posterior ethmoid and lies in relation to optic nerve.
  • When present they can increase the chance of complications during FESS.
  • Another variation of ethmoid air cells is Concha bullosa which means pneumatised middle turbinate.

questions.text: Which is not a major criteria for the diagnosis of allergic fungal sinusitis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

Fungal culture positivity

questions.text:
A 25 year old biker met an accident while practicing. He underwent splenectomy and during the surgery 2 units of B positive blood transfusion done. After few days he developed fever with chills and rigor. Clinician suspected this as malaria and ordered a peripheral blood examination which confirmed the diagnosis as Plasmodium falciparum malaria. Read the following statements regarding this condition.

I. There is no Exoerythrocytic cycle in this case
II. There is no Pre Erythrocytic cycle in this case.
III. There is no erythrocytic cycle in this case
IV. Sporozoites are the infective stage in this case
V. Trophozoites are the infective stage in this case

Which of the above statements are correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

I, II, V
Transfusion Transmitted Malaria
• There is no Exoerythrocytic cycle in this case.
• There is no Pre Erythrocytic cycle in this case.
• There is erythrocytic cycle present in this case
• Trophozoites are the infective stage and not the sporozoites in this case

choices.text: Large lysosome vesicles in neutrophils on light microscopy
Low fluorescent activity on dihydrorhodamine (DHR) flow cytometry assay
Low levels of IgM, IgE, and IgA
Positive nitroblue tetrazolium dye reduction test

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy comes to the physician because of recurrent sinusitis that has progressed to a pulmonary infection with left-sided chest pain and fever. One year ago he had an episode of Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia, and he had repeated oral candida infections until a few years ago. He also brought a HPE report as shown in the image. Which of the following would confirm the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Low fluorescent activity on dihydrorhodamine (DHR) flow cytometry assay
• This patient has chronic granulomatous disease (CGD, which usually manifests with Candida and catalase positive bacterial infections).
• CGD is caused by defective neutrophil phagocytosis due to a lack of nicotinamide adenosine dinucleotide phosphate (NADPH oxidase activity.  

 • The dihydrorhodamine (DHR) flow cytometry test assesses the production of superoxide radicals by measuring the conversion of DHR to rhodamine, a fluorescent green compound that can be detected by flow cytometry.
• Therefore, cells with low fluorescence have deficient NADPH activity.
• The image is of a non-necrotizing granuloma seen in CGD.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is HIV antibody positive and has a CD4 count of 50/mL. He has had a fever of 101°F for a few weeks and “feels tired all the time.” He has no other symptoms, and findings on physical examination are normal. Complete blood cell count, urinalysis, and chest X-ray are normal. Blood, stool, and urine cultures show no growth. A bone marrow biopsy reveals granulomas, and a culture grows an organism that is a budding yeast at 37°C but produces hyphae at 25°C. The Hyphae morphology shown in the image. Choose the
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Histoplasma capsulatum
• Thermally dimorphic (i.e., a yeast at body temperature and a mold in the soil at ambient temperature).
• The mold grows preferentially in soil enriched with bird droppings.
• Transmission by inhalation of airborne asexual spores (microconidia).
• Microconidia enter the lung and differentiate into yeast cells. The yeast cells are ingested by alveolar macrophages and multiply within them. An immune response is mounted, and granulomas form. Most infections are contained at this level, but suppression of cell-mediated immunity can lead to disseminated disease.
• Sputum or tissue can be examined microscopically and cultured on Sabouraud’s agar. Yeasts visible within macrophages. The presence of tuberculate chlamydospores in culture at 25°C is diagnostic.
• Rx - Amphotericin B or itraconazole for disseminated disease; itraconazole for pulmonary disease.

questions.text: In the laboratory, a virologist was studying the properties of mutant viruses. When she infected cells with mutant virus A, no progeny viruses were produced. When she infected cells with mutant virus B, no progeny viruses were produced. But when she infected cells with both mutant virus A and mutant virus B, progeny viruses of both virus A and virus B were produced. Which one of the following is the term that best describes this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Complementation
• Complementation can occur when either one or both of the two viruses that infect the cell have a mutation that results in a non-functional protein.
• The nonmutated virus “complements” the mutated one by making a functional protein that serves for both viruses.
• Complementation is an important method by which a helper virus permits replication of a defective virus.
• One clinically important example of complementation is hepatitis B virus providing its surface antigen to hepatitis delta virus, which is defective in its ability to produce its own outer protein.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to the hospital due to 10 days of persistent fever, chills, fatigue, and dyspnea. He had a splenectomy at age 28 after a motor vehicle accident and received the appropriate vaccines. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. He recently travelled to Connecticut for a family wedding. His temperature is 38.60 C, blood pressure is 118/70 mm Hg, and pulse is 108/min. Lung examination reveals coarse crackles. Chest x-ray reveals bilateral infiltrates. A peripheral blood smear is shown in the image. Thrombocytopenia, elevated LDH, also present. The vector responsible for this patient's current condition can also transmit which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

Borrelia burgdorferi
• This patient with an acute febrile illness, thrombocytopenia, haemolytic anaemia, elevated lactate dehydrogenase and intraerythrocytic inclusions (ring-shaped and "Maltese cross" forms) has babesiosis, a tick-borne infection.
• A definitive diagnosis can be made from a Giemsa-stained blood smear showing intraerythrocytic parasites.
• Splenectomy places patients at increased risk for severe babesiosis, which can manifest as acute respiratory distress syndrome (dyspnea, coarse crackles, bilateral infiltrates on chest x-ray).
• Babesiosis (caused by Babesia microti) and Lyme disease (caused by Borrelia burgdorferi are both transmitted by the Ixodes tick.

choices.text: It helps in specific anxiety provoking situations

questions.text: In a patient who is having anxiety disorder, you have prescribed propranolol. Which of the following statement is least likely to be correct for propranolol in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

It reduces psychological symptoms

Propranolol in this case- Used for specific anxiety provoking situations. Efficacious in controlling autonomic symptoms They do not affect the psychological symptoms (worry ,tension, anxiety Dose: 20-40mg 2hr before the performance Can aggravate depression and asthma Can produce postural hypotension.

questions.text: Patient on USG had Bosniak Type 3 Cyst and CECT was done for evaluation.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Oncocytoma
 

  • The imaging appearance of oncocytomas is difficult to distinguish from renal cell carcinoma.
  • They appear as sharply demarcated lesions of variable size, but often large at presentation.
  • A potentially helpful sign is the presence of a sharp central stellate scar as in seen in this case.
  • DSA in oncocytoma may show a spoke wheel pattern, of peripheral circumferential vessels penetrating towards the centre of the lesion.

questions.text: A 45-year-old Male presented with ataxia and urinary incontinence. He has been unwell for 6 months when he developed forgetfulness and was labelled as having dementia. 2 months later he also noticed imbalance while walking. He is obese and smokes 10 cigarettes/day for last 15 years. MRI shows dilatation of ventricles with effacement of sulci and gyri. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Normal pressure Hydrocephalus

  • This patient has a triad of ataxia, dementia and incontinence which is suggestive of normal pressure hydrocephalus.
  • Frontotemporal dementia is characterised by marked early behavioural changes.
  • In Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, there is ophthalmoplegia and psychotic features too.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male comes with chronic diarrhoea and memory loss. He is a chronic alcoholic and smoker. He noticed 6 kgs weight loss in last 3 months and has not taken any multivitamin supplements. He underwent a duodenal biopsy which shows PAS-positive organisms. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Whipple’s disease

  • Dementia and malabsorption syndrome with PAS positive organisms in biopsy are suggestive of Whipple’s disease.
  • Giardiasis can also cause chronic malabsorption but not dementia.
  • SIBO and tropical sprue would also not cause dementia and not have PAS positive organisms.

questions.text: A patient developed loss of sensation at the root of base of penis after laparoscopic hernia surgery. Which of the following nerve would have been damaged?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

Iliohypogastric nerve

  • In laparoscopic hernia surgery, the iliohypogastric nerve can be damaged and can lead to loss of sensation at the root of base of penis.
  • Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh can be damaged during long periods of lithotomy position leading to meralgia paraesthetica.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male comes with cough associated with sore throat and fever since 3 days. He also noticed passing blood in the urine. However his Serum creatinine is normal and Serum complement levels are normal. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

IgA nephropathy

  • This patient has synpharyngitic hematuria, which is characteristic of IgA nephropathy.
  • In PSGN, the hematuria occurs 2-3 weeks after the sore throat.
  • In lupus nephritis, the serum creatinine would be increased and there would be hypocomplementemia as well as no association with sore throat.
  • In vasculitis syndromes, there would be RPGN with increased serum creatinine.

choices.text: Tc scan detects meckle’s with ectopic gastric tissue
Bleeding Meckel’s is best diagnosed by Tc RBC scan
Angiography is usually diagnostic as Meckel’s has its own blood vessel (persistent vitellointestinal artery
Meckel’s is persistence of distal part of persistent vitellointestinal duct

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Meckel’s diverticulum?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Meckel’s is persistence of proximal part of persistent vitellointestinal duct

  • Meckel’s is persistence of proximal part of persistent vitellointestinal duct.
  • Ectopic gastric tissue is present in 50% of Meckel’s which is best detected by Tc scan.
  • Tc RBC scan is used for bleeding diverticulum.
  • Because Meckel’s has it own separate vessel Angiography is usually diagnostic (persistent vitellointestinal artery).

choices.text: Fall in Hb from 12 to 10 gm/dl

questions.text: A patient of RTA with grade III splenic trauma is admitted in your ward. He is on nonoperative management. What would be the reason for laparotomy on second day of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The primary reason for converting a patient with splenic trauma from nonoperative management (NOM) to surgical exploration (laparotomy) is the development of signs of ongoing active bleeding or peritoneal contamination. The presence of Pneumoperitoneum on imaging (often an X-ray or CT) is a definitive sign of a hollow viscus injury (e.g., bowel or gastric rupture). This injury introduces air and often fecal matter or gastric contents into the abdominal cavity, leading to immediate peritonitis and high risk of sepsis. This finding mandates immediate surgery regardless of the splenic injury status, thus overriding the NOM protocol.

choices.text: Tc RBC labelled MUGA scan

questions.text: All of the following are different types of perfusion scintigraphy except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Tc RBC labelled MUGA scan is not a type of perfusion scintigraphy; it is a test of cardiac function. MUGA (Multi-Gated Acquisition) scan, using Technetium (Tc) labelled Red Blood Cells ($\text{RBC}$s), is performed to image the blood pool within the heart chambers. Its primary purpose is to calculate the **Left Ventricular Ejection Fraction ($\text{LVEF}$)** and assess global and regional wall motion during the cardiac cycle (systole and diastole). It provides functional information, not myocardial blood flow (perfusion) status.

questions.text: Which of the following isotopes of iodine is used in brachytherapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Iodine-125 (I−125) is the isotope of iodine commonly used in brachytherapy. Brachytherapy involves placing a radioactive source directly inside or next to the area requiring treatment. I−125 is well-suited for this purpose because it is a low-energy gamma- and X-ray emitter with a relatively long half-life (59.4 days). Its low energy means its radiation only travels a short distance, allowing for highly localized treatment, such as in the form of small, permanent "seeds" used primarily for prostate cancer and sometimes ocular melanoma.

questions.text: Which is the first visual field defect to be seen in glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The Paracentral scotoma (often a small, isolated paracentral defect) is widely regarded as the first visual field defect to be reliably detected in early glaucoma, particularly Primary Open-Angle Glaucoma (POAG). These defects occur in the central 10 to 20 degrees of the visual field, typically nasal to the blind spot. The pathology is due to the death of nerve fibers that supply the retina's area surrounding the macula and optic disc. These fibers are highly susceptible to damage from increased intraocular pressure (IOP).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of Wormian bones on X-ray skull?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Osteopetrosis (also known as marble bone disease) is not a cause of Wormian bones. Osteopetrosis is a rare genetic disorder characterized by increased bone density due to defective osteoclast function, leading to a failure of bone resorption. Instead of causing small, extra bones within the sutures (Wormian bones), it results in excessively thick, dense, and fragile bones, often leading to bone marrow failure and cranial nerve compression.

choices.text: Assertion and reason are true and reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion and reason are true and reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is true but reason is false

questions.text:
Read the following assertion and reason.

Assertion: Tc sestamibi scan is investigation of choice to localise parathyroid adenoma.

Reason: There is differential uptake of Tc sestamibi by parathyroid cells.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Assertion is true but reason is false

  • Tc sestamibi scan is the investigation of choice to localise parathyroid adenoma.
  • At 5 minutes, it is taken up by the thyroid gland and after 1 hour, it is washed out from the thyroid but not the parathyroids.
  • Therefore, the priniciple behind this investigation is differential delayed washout.

questions.text:
In which of the following stages of neurocysticercosis can ring-enhancing lesions be found?

1. Calcified stage

2. Vesicular stage

3. Granular stage

4. Colloidal stage
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Ring-enhancing lesions are a characteristic radiological finding in Neurocysticercosis (NCC) and are found in the stages where the host's immune system is actively reacting to the dying parasite. These stages are the Colloidal stage and the Granular stage. In the Colloidal stage, the cyst fluid becomes cloudy, the parasite begins to die, and the host's immune response starts, causing inflammation around the cyst and breakdown of the blood-brain barrier (BBB). This allows contrast material (gadolinium) to leak out and show up as a ring enhancement on CT or MRI. In the subsequent Granular stage, the inflammation is still intense, and the BBB breakdown persists, resulting in continued ring enhancement until the lesion eventually resolves into a calcification.

questions.text: Dilatation ahead of a bolus of food is due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The dilation of the gut wall ahead of a bolus of food is known as the receiving or relaxation segment of the peristaltic reflex, which moves the bolus forward (or anterograde). This relaxation is primarily mediated by the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters from enteric inhibitory neurons. The most important inhibitory neurotransmitters released in this segment are Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide (VIP) and Nitric Oxide (NO). Therefore, the relaxation is due to anterograde relaxation by VIP release (and NO release, which is often listed alongside VIP), a key component of the coordinated peristaltic movement.

questions.text: Which one of the following is the diuretic of choice in patient with hepatic cirrhosis and ascites?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Eplerenone (a selective mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist) is the diuretic of choice, along with Spironolactone (a non-selective mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist), for a patient with hepatic cirrhosis and ascites. Cirrhosis causes hyperaldosteronism due to decreased hepatic metabolism of aldosterone and activation of the RAAS (Renin-Angiotensin-Aldosterone System) secondary to reduced effective circulatory volume. This excess aldosterone causes significant sodium and water retention at the collecting duct. Eplerenone specifically blocks the action of aldosterone, leading to sodium and water excretion and potassium retention, directly counteracting the pathophysiology of ascites formation.

questions.text: In which of the following dose does dopamine act on beta1 receptor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Dopamine acts primarily on the Beta1 receptor in the intermediate dose range of 2-10 μg/kg/min (micrograms per kilogram per minute). In this range, dopamine stimulates Beta1 receptors on the heart, leading to an increase in heart rate (chronotropy) and contractility (inotropy). This effect makes dopamine a useful drug for improving cardiac output in patients with cardiogenic shock or heart failure, albeit it is now less favored than alternatives like norepinephrine or dobutamine.

questions.text: Weakly acidic drugs binds with which of the following protein?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Weakly acidic drugs primarily bind to Albumin in the plasma. Albumin is the most abundant protein in the plasma and has multiple binding sites, including a high-affinity site (Site I) that preferentially binds acidic drugs (e.g., Warfarin, Phenytoin, NSAIDs). This binding is crucial because only the unbound (free) fraction of the drug is pharmacologically active and available to exert its effect, be metabolized, or be eliminated.

questions.text: Which of the following is a parametric test of significance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The ANOVA test (Analysis of Variance) is a parametric test of significance. Parametric tests are statistical methods that assume the data follows a specific probability distribution, usually the normal distribution, and that the population parameters (like the mean and variance) can be estimated. ANOVA compares the means of three or more independent groups to determine if at least one group mean is statistically significantly different from the others, requiring the assumption of normality and homogeneity of variances.

questions.text: The maximum age of administration of DPT vaccine is?

This is because the full-strength Pertussis component (P), which is part of the DPT (or DTwP/DTaP) vaccine, is associated with a higher risk of adverse reactions, particularly fever and local reactions, as a child gets older. After the 7th birthday, the D and T components are given without the P component (as DT) or, more commonly, the lower-strength adult formulation, Tdap (Tetanus, reduced Diphtheria, and acellular Pertussis), is used.

choices.text: Replication and immediate crossover of the leading strand

questions.text: It is well known that DNA polymerases synthesize DNA only in the 5' to 3' direction. Yet, at the replication fork, both strands of parental DNA are being replicated with the synthesis of new DNA. How is it possible that while one strand is being synthesized in the 5' to 3' direction, the other strand appears to be synthesized in the 3' to 5' direction? This apparent paradox is explained by
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Okazaki fragments
 

  • Since both strands of parental DNA serve as templates for the synthesis of new DNA, it appears that DNA synthesis must be 5' to 3' for one daughter strand and 3' to 5' for the other daughter strand at the replication fork.
  • Despite the apparent need for 3' to 5' synthesis, all DNA polymerases and repair enzymes can only synthesize DNA in the 5' to 3' direction.
  • The apparent contradiction is solved by understanding that one strand of DNA is synthesized continuously in the 5' to 3' direction while the other strand is made up of small fragments known as Okazaki fragments.
  • The small Okazaki fragments are, in fact, synthesized in a 5' to 3' direction and then joined together by DNA ligase. Each Okazaki fragment is about 1000 nucleotides long.
  • Thus, while the overall direction of growth of the lagging strand that is made up of small fragments is in fact in the 3' to 5' direction, the actual polymerization of individual nucleotides is in the 5' to 3' direction.
  • Crossing over of the DNA strands does not occur during replication.

questions.text: WHO recommended mass drug administration is indicated for all except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Scabies is not a condition for which the WHO currently recommends global or national Mass Drug Administration (MDA) programs. MDA involves treating an entire target population (e.g., all people in an endemic area) with a single dose of medication, regardless of individual infection status, to interrupt transmission of a disease or treat a widespread deficiency. While mass treatment of Scabies might be used in specific, closed communities (like institutions or prisons) during an outbreak, it is not listed among the WHO's priority MDA programs aimed at eliminating or controlling Neglected Tropical Diseases (NTDs) or major nutritional deficiencies.
