- Phosphate transporter
- Adenine nucleotide translocase (ADP – ATP transporter)

choices.text: Intralesional Cidofovir is helpful to reduce the recurrence rate
Microlaryngeal surgery with CO2 laser is the primary modality of treatment

questions.text: An 8-year-old child with no history of vocal abuse presented with the chief complaint of hoarseness of voice for last 3 months which is progressively increasing in severity. His parents give history of repeated episodes of breathlessness since the age of 7 years. Child was sent for endoscopy which reveals multiple small papillomas along vocal cords bilaterally as shown in given slide. Which of the following is not appropriate statement regarding diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

It’s a purely glottic entity

  • Juvenile papillomas of larynx (recurrent respiratory papillomatosis) is caused by HPV-6,11.
  • The infection is transmitted from mother at the time of birth. They can spread downwards to trachea bronchi lungs.
  • Typically seen in young children with chronic hoarseness and respiratory distress.
  • CO2 laser is the treatment of choice.
  • Recurrences are common after surgery.
  • They are premalignant
  • Interferon alpha and intralesional cidofovir is helpful in management.

questions.text: A 18-year-old man presented with left sided ear discharge for 1 year with dull ear ache. On examination left tympanic membrane is thickened and chalky white in appearance and a mass is seen in the posterior canal wall on left side. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

Keratosis obturans
 

  • This patient with a thickened and chalky white tympanic membrane and a mass in EAC has keratosis obturans.
  • It is the accumulation of a large plug of keratin in the external auditory meatus.
  • Seen between 5-20 years of age.
  • Clinical features include pain, ear discharge, hearing loss and tinnitus.
  • In CSOM, there would be perforation, hearing loss and ear discharge.
  • In otitis externa, there would be history of swimming along with ear pain and discharge.
  • In carcinoma of EAC, there would be no tympanic membrane thickening or chalky white appearance.

questions.text: An individual is brought to casualty with complaint of headache, drowsiness, anxiety, photophobia. On examination he has extrasystoles, gynaecomastia and trigeminal neuralgia. What could be the possible cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Digitalis toxicity

  • Digitalis is a cardiac Na-K-ATPase inhibitor. It can cause extrasystoles, trigeminal neuralgia and gynaecomastia too.
  • Curare can lead to flaccid paralysis and respiratory failure.
  • Thallium poisoning can lead to alopecia and ascending paralysis similar to GBS.
  • Cerebra thevetia also has a cardiac glycoside as its conteny. However, there would be no gynecomastia.

choices.text: Prominent sacral part of chilotic line
Broad and deep Preauricular sulcus

questions.text: Which of the following findings is not suggestive of female skeleton?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The finding that is not suggestive of a female skeleton is a Prominent sacral part of the chilotric line. The chilotric line (also called the chilotic line) is the ridge that runs along the lateral aspect of the sacral alae. A prominent or well-marked chilotric line (especially the sacral part) is typically a feature of a male sacrum. Conversely, the sacrum in females is generally wider and shorter, and the chilotric line is usually less prominent.

questions.text: A 40-year-old Japanese tourist comes to your clinic with severe headaches, palpitations, burning and pain in his hands since the last 5 days. On examination, you notice erythema and peeling of his hands. His BP is 160/100 mm Hg and HR is 115/min. You also notice a strawberry tongue. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Mercury poisoning

  • This patient has acrodynia along with features of catecholamine excess suggestive of mercury poisoning. Eating excess sushi can predispose to this.
  • It can mimic pheochromocytoma and Kawasaki disease.
  • Arsenic poisoning presents with rash, diarrhea and neuropathy.

choices.text: Sec 316 IPC – Preventing a child from being born alive
Sec 302 IPC – Punishment of murder

questions.text: Which of the following IPC is mentioned incorrectly?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The statement "Sec 316 IPC – Preventing a child from being born alive" is incorrectly matched. Section 316 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) deals with the offense of "Causing death of quick unborn child by act amounting to culpable homicide". This section covers the situation where a fetus, which is capable of being born alive (quick unborn child), is killed by an act that would amount to culpable homicide if the child were already born. The offense of preventing a child from being born alive is covered by a different section (Sec 315 IPC - Act done with intent to prevent child being born alive or to cause it to die after birth).

questions.text:
Arrange the following in the order of putrefactive changes.

1. Brain

2. Uterus

3. Heart

4. Larynx

5. Muscle
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The correct order of putrefactive changes (decomposition) from fastest to slowest is generally determined by the amount of fluid and air (oxygen) in the tissue. Organs rich in fluid, blood, and air-containing spaces putrefy quickly, while dense, muscular, or relatively sterile organs putrefy slowly. The fastest to decompose are the Larynx (4) and Brain (1). The larynx contains air spaces and mucosa, and the brain is soft, vascular, and rich in water and lipids. The decomposition then proceeds to the Heart (3), which is dense muscle but highly vascular. The Uterus (2), especially in a non-pregnant state, is thick, muscular, and relatively resistant to decay due to its dense connective tissue and low fluid content. The Muscle (5) is generally slow to putrefy because it is dense tissue and relatively low in blood and oxygen compared to the other organs. Therefore, the sequence is  4 > 1 > 3 > 2 > 5

choices.text: It is caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa
Gallium scan is used for diagnosis while ESR at 2 weeks is prognostic
It can cause skull base osteomyelitis

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about malignant otitis externa?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Gallium scan is used for diagnosis while ESR at 2 weeks is prognostic

  • Malignant otitis externa is a skull base osteomyelitis which is caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa in diabetic patients.
  • Tc99 scan is the investigation of choice while Gallium scan and ESR at 2 weeks are prognostic

questions.text: A 32-year-old male comes to the emergency with acute onset severe pain in his right eye and blurring of vision since the past 24 hours. He also complains of flashes and floaters. On examination, he has keratoconjunctivitis. A slit lamp examination reveals uveitis. A fundoscopy is performed and is shown below. On asking, he reveals that he has dated several men before and does not use condoms regularly. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

VZV retinitis

  • This patient likely has untreated HIV predisposing him for VZV retinitis, which is an acute, rapidly progressive, necrotizing retinitis with associated conjunctivitis, keratitis and uveitis, along with peripheral pale lesions and central necrosis on fundoscopy.
  • In CMV retinitis, there is pizza pie appearance and painless visual loss.
  • Toxoplasma chorioretinitis can present with retinal and choroidal scarring but not necrotising retinitis
  • In Candida endophthalmitis, patient will have mild or no pain ad will have white irregular mounds on retina in fundoscopy.

questions.text: All of the following are used to test colour vision except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The Pelli-Robson chart is not a test used to evaluate color vision; it is a test used to measure contrast sensitivity. Contrast sensitivity is the ability to distinguish an object from its background at different levels of contrast. The Pelli-Robson chart uses large letters of fixed size but with progressively decreasing contrast as you move down the chart. It assesses visual function that is often affected early in diseases like cataract, optic neuritis, and glaucoma, which is distinct from the ability to perceive and distinguish different colors.

choices.text: Cell swelling, pyknosis, swelling of endoplasmic reticulum.
Cell swelling, membrane blebs, membrane damage.
Cells swelling, membrane blebs, hydropic change.

questions.text: A 60-year old man presented to emergency with chest pain, radiating to the left arm for last 15 minutes. Blood examination shows normal levels troponin and creatinine Kinase enzymes. The doctors at the emergency room successfully save the patient with treatment. If it would have been possible to examine microscopic sections during the episode which of the following would have been most likely cellular change?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Cell swelling, membrane blebs, hydropic change

  • This patient is having pain which lasted 15 minutes and no elevated enzymes meaning reversible injury.
  • Cell swelling, membrane blebs, hydropic change are all features of reversible cell injury.
  • Myelin figures, membrane damage and swelling of endoplasmic reticulum are all features of irreversible cell damage.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man had surgery 3 months ago. Now he has a small 0.3 cm nodule beneath the skin at the incision site that was sutured. Which of the following cell types is most likely to be most characteristic of the inflammatory response in this situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Giant cell

  • The suture is a foreign material and produces a foreign body reaction.
  • Persistence of the stimulus recruits macrophages that are activated and transformed to giant cells, in this case foreign body giant cells
  • Mast cells are mediators of allergic reactions.
  • Eosinophilia is seen in parasitic infections.
  • Neutrophils are characteristically seen in acute inflammatory infiltrates.

questions.text: A 58-year old man presents with epistaxis. Biopsy from the mass shows small round cells centred around the blood vessel. Immunohistochemistry shows the neoplastic cells are CD45 (LCA)+, CD3-, CD4- CD20-, CD16+, EBV+. Which of the following is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Extra nodal NK cell lymphoma

  • The histological description is Angiocentric pattern of lymphoma cells and IHC is positive for CD16 which is a marker of NK cells.
  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is seen classically in middle aged patients, typically seen in the Chinese due to EBV infection. They present with unilateral serous otitis media, facial numbness and a mass in the nasopharynx.
  • In anaplastic large cell lymphoma there are large pleomorphic lymphoid cells with abundant cytoplasm and horseshoe shaped nuclei positive for CD30.
  • Hodgkin's lymphoma is positive for CD15 and CD30. Job

choices.text: N 5, N 10-methylene tetrahydrofolate
N5 formyl folate

questions.text: Which of the following is involved in formation of d-TMP from d-UMP?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

N 5, N 10-methylene tetrahydrofolate

  • N 5, N 10-methylene tetrahydrofolate is the donor of methyl group in the reaction catalysed by thymidylate synthase.
  • In this process N 5, N 10-methylene tetrahydrofolate is converted to dihydrofolic acid(DHF).
  • DHF reductase then converts DHF to THF.

choices.text: Primary active transport
Secondary active co-transport

questions.text: After a long workout, a third-year medical student drinks a bottle of glucose and electrolyte containing sports drink. Which of the following is a major mechanism for absorption of glucose from the small intestine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Secondary active co-transport

  • The major mechanism of glucose absorption in the lumen of the gut is by SGLT-1 (secondary active co-transport).
  • Glucose leaves the basal side of the cell by facilitated diffusion (GLUT-2).

choices.text: Plasma colloid osmotic pressure
Vena cava hydrostatic pressure
Interstitial fluid colloid osmotic pressure

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is suffering from congestive cardiac failure. Tests by the cardiologist reveal a right atrial pressure of 10 mm Hg. An increase in which of the following would be expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Vena cava hydrostatic pressure

  • Increase in the RAP to 10 mm Hg would tend to decrease the venous return to the heart and increase the vena cava hydrostatic pressure.
  • Decrease in venous return will also decrease the cardiac output.

choices.text: + 2 cm H2O
+ 0.5 cm H2O
0 cm H2O
-1 cm H2O

questions.text: The airway pressure of a normal 77-year-old man is approximately 1 cm H2O during expiration. What is his airway pressure during inspiration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

-1 cm H2O

  • Expansion of the chest cavity during inspiration causes the airway pressure (also k/a intrapulmonary pressure or alveolar pressure) to become sub atmospheric, averaging about -1 cm H2O during quiet inspiration, resulting in movement of air into the lungs.

choices.text: Immune complex deposition
Delayed effects of snake venom
Anaphylaxis due to ASV
Delayed type of hypersensitivity

questions.text: A 35-year healthy man had a snake bite, he was administered polyvalent anti Snake Venom (ASV) and was discharged from the hospital after a week. Three days after discharge he develops high grade fever, arthralgia, lymphadenopathy, facial swelling and erythema in hands and feet. Which of the following explains the manifestations?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

Immune complex deposition stop

  • This is a classical presentation of serum sickness disease (SSD) which is type III HSR following antibody injection.
  • The ASV will contain animal antibodies which will be recognised as foreign by the patient’s immune system which mounts an immune response, and the antibodies form immune complexes and deposit in multiple locations leading to generalised disease.
  • SSD can occur after injections anti-thymocyte immunoglobulin and even after monoclonal antibodies

choices.text: Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
Autoimmune haemolytic anemia
Iron deficiency anemia

questions.text: A 38-year-old lady presents with easy fatiguability, peripheral blood examination shows Hb 8 g/dl, MCH 27, MCV 80 fL, RBC count 2.9 million, reticulocyte count 0.5%. Which of the following is likely a diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

 Aplastic anemia

  • Normocytic normochromic anemia with reticulocytopenia (<1%) makes the diagnosis of aplastic anemia more likely in this patient.
  • In paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria and autoimmune hemolytic anemia, the patient is expected to have reticulocytosis.
  • In iron deficiency anemia the MCV and the MCH are expected to be low.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents with a diffuse scaly skin rash of 4 weeks duration. Biopsy of skin lesion reveals mycosis fungoides. Which of the following IHC markers would be most useful for identifying malignant cells in the skin of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

CD4

  • Mycosis fungoides is a cutaneous T cell lymphoma and is therefore CD 4 and CD 3 positive.
  • Cytokeratin is marker for carcinoma.
  • Desmin is marker for Muscle tumors.
  • HMB-45 is marker for melanoma.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida visits your office in the 12th week of pregnancy. A routine CBC is as follows: Haemoglobin 12 gm/dl, haematocrit 45, reticulocyte count 1.8%, RBC count 6.5 million and a peripheral blood smear shows microcytic hypochromic picture. Serum iron is 90 ug/dL and serum ferritin is 80 ug/dL along with a TIBC of 300 ug/dL Which of the following is the most appropriate step to be taken?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Advise HPLC

  • The patient is having microcytic hypochromic picture with increased RBC count raising a suspicion of thalassemia minor.
  • Her MCV = HCTx10/RBC count is 69 FL.
  • Her Mentzer is = MCV/RBC is 69/6.5 = 10.6 which is far less than 13.
  • This further is highly suspicious of Thalassemia minor, thus a HPLC is advised to rule out the same

choices.text: Associated with polymyalgia rheumatica
Raised ESR is a common finding
Fragmentation of internal elastic lamina is seen

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman complains of a throbbing unilateral headache and vision problems. She reports weight loss and mandibular pain while eating. The patient also has a history of recurrent bouts of fever accompanied by malaise and muscle aches. Which of the following is not true about the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

ANCA positive

  • History is suggestive of giant cell arteritis
  • Histology shows granulomatous inflammation, giant cells and break of internal elastic lamina
  • Associated with polymyalgia rheumatica and raised ESR.
  • ANCA negative condition

questions.text: A 13-year-old female patient presented to the emergency with acute diffuse abdominal pain for the past 12 hours.. A tense sausage shaped mass is felt in the upper abdomen. Gums and lips show dark spots. Further investigations reveal multiple sessile and pedunculated polyps in the GI tract. A biopsy performed showed a characteristic histopathological appearance of arborizing smooth muscles and glands. The family was then counselled about risk of breast and pancreatic cancer in the family, and screening of other members as well. Which gene mutation was found?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

LKB1

  • Also called STK11 gene
  • Hamartomatous polyps with arborizing smooth muscle fibers and mucocutaneous melanosis are suggestive of Peutz Jegher syndrome.
  • Increased risk of breast and pancreatic cancer.
  • BRCA1 mutation is a feature of hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndrome.
  • MSH1 mutation is seen in hereditary non polyposis colon cancer syndrome, also known as lynch syndrome. There is increased risk for colorectal, endometrial and ovarian cancers.
  • PTEN mutation is seen in Cowden syndrome in which there is an increased risk for both benign and malignant tumours of the breast, thyroid, endometrium, colorectum and the skin.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs would be best to use to treat irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) in a 58-year-old woman?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Alosetron

  • Alosetron has been shown to provide some relief of symptoms in irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
  • Infliximab is a biologic agent used in the management of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)
  • Diphenoxylate is a morphine analogue used to treat diarrhoea
  • Orlistat is an agent used to manage obesity.

questions.text: A woman who is undergoing an endocrine work-up to diagnose the cause of a large multinodular goitre develops atrial fibrillation. Which of the following would be best to treat this arrhythmia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Propranolol

  • Hyperthyroidism increases the expression β-adrenoceptors.
  • β-Adrenoceptor antagonists such as propranolol can actually decrease symptoms of hyperthyroidism by directly blocking the receptors as well as acting as inhibitors of 5’-deiodinase.
  • Verapamil can be used to treat rapid ventricular rates in atrial fibrillation but it is not the drug of choice as it does not inhibit 5’-deiodinase.
  • Digitalis is the drug of choice for atrial fibrillation in congestive heart failure.
  • Bretylium is a class III antiarrhythmic agent which acts by blocking the potassium channels.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man has been smoking two packs of cigarettes a day for the last 20 years. He is concerned that his health has deteriorated, and he has a persistent hacking cough. He also states that he doesn’t want to “get lung cancer and die, like my father did.” He has tried nicotine patches with no success and wants to know if there is any “pill” he could try. What medication could the physician recommend?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Bupropion

  • Bupropion is an atypical heterocyclic antidepressant that is useful as an aid in smoking cessation.
  • Mirtazapine is another atypical agent used in the treatment of depression that blocks both serotonin and α-adrenergic receptors.
  • Citalopram is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) which are typically not used for smoking cessation.
  • Buspirone is an antianxiety drug useful in situations where nonsedating agents are favoured.

questions.text: An 76-year-old woman who is taking multiple medications for her “heart disease” is prescribed gentamicin for diverticulitis. After a few days of taking the antibiotic, she complains of dizziness and tinnitus. What “heart medication” might she be on?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Furosemide

  • Ototoxicity, as demonstrated by tinnitus and dizziness, is a common side effect of loop diuretics.
  • This effect is magnified when aminoglycoside antibiotics are added to the regimen.
  • Spironolactone is not associated with tinnitus.
  • Hydrochlorothiazide can cause gout in susceptible individuals.
  • Mannitol and urea are osmotic diuretics and are not indicated in patients with heart disease, especially congestive heart failure (CHF).

questions.text: Intravenous administration of epinephrine to a patient result in a severe decrease in diastolic pressure and an increase in cardiac output. Which of the following drugs might the patient have previously taken that could account for this unexpected effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Prazosin

  • Prazosin is the only drug listed that blocks postjunctional α1-adrenoceptors and inhibits epinephrine-mediated vasoconstriction.
  • This phenomenon is referred to as vasomotor reversal of Dale.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus is brought to the emergency department. He was unconscious and hypotensive when found, but in the ED he is alert and complains of severe abdominal pain and shortness of breath. The patient is also febrile and has sinus tenderness with erythema in the paranasal sinus, and a bloody discharge around his nose. He states that he has had double vision for the past 3 days. Physical examination shows that he cannot move his left eye in any direction. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Mucor species

  • This diabetic patient with sinusitis as well as a palsy involving several cranial nerves has symptoms suggestive of invasive zygomycosis from Mucor species.
  • Mucor species are molds with irregular non-septate, hyphae, branching at wide angles ( >90 degrees).
  • Invasive infection with these ubiquitous fungi is mostly seen in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis and those who are immunosuppressed (eg, because of hematologic malignancies).
  • Surgical debridement and high doses of amphotericin B are used to treat mucormycosis, but mortality is nevertheless very high

choices.text: Hepatitis C virus

questions.text: A 30-year-old NRI missionary who recently returned from a trip to South America presents to the clinic with symptoms of high fever, headache, and back pain. Physical examination reveals yellow pigmentation at the conjunctiva of the eyes, and the patient vomits during the visit. The vomitus contains dark-colored blood. Results of a reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction test are positive. Which of the following viruses is a member of the same virus family as the one most likely causing this patient's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Hepatitis C virus

  • Yellow fever is caused by a mosquito-borne virus belonging to the family Flaviviridae; this virus is generally transmit ted by Aedes mosquitoes.
  • Symptoms generally include high fever, black vomitus (dark-colored blood in the vomitus) as a result of gastrointestinal bleeding, jaundice, headache, and back pain.
  • Diagnosis can be confirmed by testing with reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction within 6 - 10 days. Liver biopsy can show signs of Councilman bodies (acidophilic inclusions in liver). However, due to the bleeding tendency of yellow fever patients, liver biopsy is generally not recommended and only advisable post-mortem to confirm the cause of death.
  • Preventive treatment includes the use of live-attenuated vaccines before one travels to an endemic area (eg, South America, Africa . The hepatitis C virus is another member of the family Flaviviridae, a linear SS( + RNA viral family with icosahedral capsids. Other members of the family Flaviviridae of viruses include dengue, St. Lou is encephalitis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile virus, and Zika virus.

choices.text: Directly acts as an adenylate cyclase
Inactivates elongation factor 2
Permanently activates Gs
Permanently inactivates Gi

questions.text: A 50-year-old man begins to have profuse, non-bloody, watery diarrhea 2 days after arriving from Bangladesh to serve as an aid worker. A stool sample looks like water after rice has been cooked in it, and a smear shows no WBCs. His mucous membranes are dry, and his skin shows signs of tenting. Subsequently, electrolyte abnormalities develop that lead to cardiac and renal failure. What is the mechanism of action of the exotoxin produced by the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Permanently activates Gs

  • This patient most likely has cholera, caused by the bacterium Vibrio cholerae, which is marked by watery stools (often called "rice-water" stool). This illness is not accompanied by abdominal pain.
  • Cholera toxin enters the cell and constitutively activates the Gs protein through ADP ribosylation.
  • This results in a high cAMP level, which activates the CFTR (cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator channel, leading to a large efflux of chlorine and other ions into the gastrointestinal lumen.
  • The result is extremely watery diarrhea accompanied by electrolyte imbalances
  • The diphtheria toxin inactivates elongation factor 2.
  • The pertussis toxin permanently inactivates Gi.

questions.text: After 11 days in the intensive care unit following an automobile accident, an 18-year-old woman develops increased urinary urgency, burning during urination, and lower abdominal pain. When her urine is cultured, a red pigment is observed in the Petri dish. What is the most likely organism causing these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Serratia marcescens

  • Serratia is a common cause of nosocomial urinary tract infections, along with E. coli, Proteus, Klebsiella and Pseudomonas.
  • Some strains produce a non-diffusible red pigment called prodigiosin.
  • Nosocomial infections generally are more resistant than community acquired infect ions.
  • Serratia is a gram-negative, facultatively anaerobic bacillus.
  • Proteus UTI associated with renal stones

choices.text: Adenylate cyclase toxin

questions.text: A 9-year-old school student is brought to her pediatrician with complaints of fever, cough, and fatigue for the past 2 weeks. The physician notices that the patient is having intermittent bouts of many coughs in a single breath, followed by a deep inspiration. Choose the correct toxin.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

Adenylate cyclase toxin

  • This patient is presenting with a classic case of whooping cough caused by Bordetella pertussis.
  • Selective medium is Regan Lowe medium and produces Mercury drop colonies.
  • Important virulent factor is Adenyl cyclase toxin acts on cAMP.
  • Pertussis toxin, Tracheal cytotoxin, Filamentous hemagglutinin are other toxins.

choices.text: Live attenuated and subcutaneous route
Live attenuated and intramuscular route
Killed and subcutaneous route

questions.text: A vaccine is given in some parts of country to prevent acute encephalitis syndrome. According to UIP which of the following is true regarding the same?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The vaccine given in parts of India under the Universal Immunization Programme (UIP) to prevent Acute Encephalitis Syndrome (AES) is primarily the Japanese Encephalitis (JE) vaccine. The specific formulation used in the UIP is the live attenuated SA14-14-2 strain. This JE vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine and is administered via the subcutaneous route. It is given as a single dose to children in endemic districts.

choices.text: Purulent rhinorrhea . Fever . Headache . Altered mental status
Fever . Altered mental status . Purulent rhinorrhea . Headache
Headache . Fever . Altered mental status . Purulent rhinorrhea
Altered mental status . Purulent rhinorrhea . Headache . Fever

questions.text: Which of the presenting symptoms of an intracranial complication of sinusitis, in the order of most to least common, is listed below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Headache . Fever . Altered mental status . Purulent rhinorrhea

  • Interestingly, purulent rhinorrhea, a cardinal symptom of acute sinusitis, is rare in patients who present with intracranial complications of sinusitis.
  • Headache is the most common presenting symptom, followed by fever and altered mental status

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman has relapsing remitting multiple sclerosis. She has experienced two attacks of disease previously that have left her with residual lower extremity weakness. She was initially treated with glucocorticoids with some improvement in her symptoms. However, she is currently only able to walk with a rolling walker for about 100 m. A prior antibody test shows that she is positive for reactivity to the JC virus. You are planning to start a disease-modifying therapy. Which of the following is least appropriate for this individual?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Natalizumab

  • Natalizumab is not recommended in this patient due to the presence of antibody to JC virus.
  • About half of the population is antibody positive for JC virus, indicating past exposure typically with an asymptomatic infection.
  • JC virus is implicated in the development of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy.
  • This life-threatening condition has occurred in 0.3% of all patients treated with natalizumab and in about 0.6% of patients who are positive for JC virus antibody. T
  • he risk is lower in the first year of treatment and increases thereafter.
  • Thus, natalizumab should not be used in this patient unless she has failed alternative therapies or if the disease course has been particularly aggressive.

questions.text: Testicular tenderness is a feature of which vasculitis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Testicular tenderness is a classic feature associated with Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN). PAN is a systemic necrotizing vasculitis that primarily targets medium-sized arteries. When PAN affects the testicular arteries, it can lead to testicular pain and tenderness (orchitis) due to arteritis, thrombosis, and subsequent infarction of testicular tissue. Testicular involvement is relatively common in PAN and is an important diagnostic clue.

choices.text: Alpha 1 subunit of type 4 collagen
Alpha 2 subunit of type 4 collagen
Alpha 3 subunit of type 4 collagen
Alpha 4 subunit of type 4 collagen

questions.text: 30-year-old male presented with haemoptysis and RPGN. He is a smoker and does not give history of previous similar episode. Renal Biopsy reveals Linear Ig deposits on the GBM. The most likely finding on serology is antibody against:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Alpha 3 subunit of type 4 collagen (Goodpasture’s antigen)
 

  • Good Pastures syndrome (Pulmonary Renal syndrome) is an auto-immune disease.
  • This is characterized by lung hemorrhage, glomerulonephritis, and circulating antibody to basement membrane, usually in young men.
  • Hemoptysis may precede nephritis. Lung involvement is more common among smokers for unknown reasons.
  • Rapidly progressive renal failure is typical
  • Circulating anti – glomerular basement membrane (GBM) antibody and linear immune – fluorescence on renal biopsy establishes the diagnosis
  • Plasma exchange may produce remission.

questions.text: Following are the causes of enlarged kidney in CKD except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Alport’s syndrome

  • Alport’s syndrome patients have a shrunken kidney.
  • Causes of enlarged kidney in CKD include:
    a. DM nephropathy
    b. ADPKD
  • c. Renal Amyloidosis (Myeloma kidney)
  • d. HIVAN

choices.text: Gastroesophageal reflux disease
Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth
Primary biliary cirrhosis

questions.text: Which of the following gastrointestinal disorders is often associated with Sjogren syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Primary biliary cirrhosis

  • Sjogren syndrome may develop in as many as 40%–65% of patients with primary biliary cirrhosis.
  • Typical symptoms include dry mouth (xerostomia) and dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis and may precede PBC-related symptoms.
  • Gastroesophageal reflux disease, small intestinal bacterial overgrowth, and gallstone pancreatitis are not associated with Sjögren syndrome.
  • Ulcerative colitis is associated with several extraintestinal manifestations, such as uveitis, but not Sjögren syndrome.

questions.text: All of the following are branches of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The Superior gluteal artery is not a branch of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery; it is the sole branch of the posterior division of the internal iliac artery. The posterior division is typically short and gives off the superior gluteal artery (which exits the pelvis above the piriformis muscle) and two smaller parietal branches: the iliolumbar and lateral sacral arteries.

questions.text: A patient is given the tetanus toxoid vaccine after an injury. Post vaccination, the nurse noted some asymmetry of the shoulder. Which of the following structure is involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The correct structure involved is the Deltoid muscle. When a vaccine, such as the tetanus toxoid, is injected improperly—too high, too deep, or with irritating contents—it can cause a condition known as Shoulder Injury Related to Vaccine Administration (SIRVA). The resulting pain, inflammation, and limited range of motion can lead to muscular atrophy due to disuse, or direct local inflammatory damage to the muscle tissue. Since the Deltoid is the intended and primary site for intramuscular injection and forms the contour of the shoulder, its atrophy or persistent inflammation/damage would lead to the noted asymmetry of the shoulder.

questions.text: If cytosine in DNA is deaminated, the uracil residue that results may be removed by?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

A glycosylase

  • Although other enzymes are involved in the repair of DNA, only glycosylases are able to remove bases by cleaving N-glycosidic bonds.
  • Endonucleases and exonucleases cleave bonds between 2 nucleotides.
  • Polynucleotide ligase catalyses the formation of phosphodiester bonds between nucleotides.

choices.text: Nasogastric tube insertion

questions.text: A 32-year-old man was brought to the emergency department after he was hit by a truck while walking. His HR was 119/min and respiratory rate was 26/min. His Chest ̣X-ray is shown below. Which of the following would be contraindicated to do in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

ICD insertion

  • This patient has traumatic diaphragmatic rupture following blunt abdominal trauma.
  • ICD can injure the bowel and hence is contraindicated
  • Nasogastric tube will be beneficial as it will decompress the bowel.
  • Log roll can be done to examine the back
  • Endotracheal intubation can be done if there is respiratory distress.

choices.text: Primary repair with prolene sutures is the procedure of choice
Repair with reverse saphenous graft is preferred
PTFE graft is the synthetic graft of choice
Repair with saphenous venous patch is not preferrable in this case

questions.text: A 22-year-old lady presents with a hematoma over the right arm region following a history of stab injury. Radial and ulnar pulses were absent on the right side. A  3 cm longitudinal tear was noted in the brachial artery. Which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

Primary repair with prolene sutures is the procedure of choice

  • For repair of a defect, reverse saphenous vein graft is preferred over synthetic graft
  • Among synthetic grafts, PTFE is the graft of choice.
  • Saphenous vein patch is used if only a portion of the circumference of the artery is damaged.
  • Primary repair is done if there is no defect.

choices.text: Surgeon’s knot
Reef knot
Granny knot
Mattress knot

questions.text: Identify the following knot.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 

Surgeon’s knot

choices.text: This position is mainly used for posterior cranial fossa surgery
Main complication is CSF leak
This is called fowler position
In standard Fowler’s position head of the bed is kept at 45-60 degrees

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement about following surgical position?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Main complication is CSF leak

  • This is Fowler’s position used during posterior cranial fossa surgeries.
  • Its main complication is air embolism
  • In standard Fowler’s position, the head of the bed is kept at 45-60 degrees.

choices.text: Conservative management, analgesics and O2
Conservative management but strapping of chest should be done.
Right ICD insertion
Positive pressure ventilation.

questions.text: A patient after sustaining severe chest trauma was brought to the emergency department where he was noted to have dyspnoea, bony crepitus over right hemithorax and paradoxical movement of chest during respiration. During evaluation RR was 36/ min and SpO2 was 60 mm Hg. Which is the best treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Positive pressure ventilation

  • This patient has flail chest caused by fracture of 3 or more consecutive ribs in 2 or more places.
  • Due to this, the flail segment moves inward with inspiration and outward with expiration.
  • Endotracheal intubation and positive pressure ventilation is the treatment of choice.
  • There is no role of ICD insertion or strapping of chest.
  • Analgesics and oxygen can be given but the first line treatment is positive pressure ventilation.

choices.text: Reduction of shearing pressure on the aorta with esmolol is of utmost importance
Commonest site of intimal tear is within 2-3 cm of aortic valve
External rupture can cause fatal pericardial tamponade
Best treatment for type A Stanford is conservative but for type B is surgical.

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement about aortic dissection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Best treatment for type A Stanford is conservative but for type B is surgical
 

  • It is the commonest aortic emergency. Most commonly seen between 50 and 70 years
  • Rupture can occur back into the lumen or externally in pericardium/ mediastinum
  • External rupture often results in fatal pericardial tamponade
  • Commonest site of intimal tear is within 2-3 cm of aortic valve
  • Most commonly involved are renal, spinal, coronary or iliac arteries
  • All patients require urgent management of associated hypertension
  • Type A dissections usually require surgical intervention
  • Dissection excised and aorta replaced with graft
  • An evolving CVA or established renal failure are contraindications to surgery

choices.text: Partial thickness grafts elicit more secondary contraction than full thickness graft
In partial thickness graft hair follicles are not grafted
Z -plasty is an example of rotational flaps
Most commonly used flap in radical neck dissection reconstruction is pectoralis major flap

questions.text: Which of the following statements about grafts/flaps is false?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Z-plasty is an example of rotational flap
 

  • Full thickness grafts have more primary contraction and partial thickness grafts have more secondary contraction
  • Z-plasty is an example of transposition flap not rotational flap (other examples of transposition flap are Bilobed flap and Lindberg flap/rhomboid flap).
  • Most common angle used in Z-plasty is 60 degree which provides 75% gain in length.
  • In partial thickness graft, hair follicles are not grafted.
  • Most commonly used flap in radical neck dissection reconstruction is pectoralis major flap

choices.text: For Pleomorphic adenoma involving deep lobe, total conservative parotidectomy is surgery of choice
Most of Parotid stones are radio-opaque
Adenoid cystic tumour has a tendency to spread along the nerve
Stafne bone cyst is an ectopic salivary gland

questions.text: Which of the following statements about salivary glands is false?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Most of parotid stones are radio-opaque

  • Pleomorphic adenoma is treated by superficial parotidectomy but if deep lobe is involved than total conservative parotidectomy is preferred.
  • Most of parotid stones are radiolucent while most of submandibular stones are radio-opaque.
  • Adenoid cystic tumour is most common in minor salivary gland in hard palate and have a tendency to spread along the nerves.
  • Stafne bone cyst is ectopic submandibular gland in mandibular bone.

choices.text: Can occur up to 14 days of surgery
In case of implants, can occur up to 6 month of surgery
Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause
Clean shaving can prevent SSIs

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about surgical site infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause
 

  • SSI can occur up to 30 days after surgery and up to 1 year in case of implants.
  • Clean shaving has not proved beneficial in reducing SSI.
  • Preoperative antibiotics, bathing with chlorhexidine and hair clipping can reduce the incidence of SSI rather than shaving.

choices.text: Papillary cancer thyroid

questions.text: A 42-year-old lady presented with painful neck swelling for 2 weeks, fever, weight loss, excessive sweating and tremors. Her thyroid profile showed high T3 and T4 and low TSH. Iodine scan showed a cold thyroid. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

Thyroiditis
 

  • If thyroid scan is cold but patient has features of thyrotoxicosis, then the thyrotoxicosis is not due to over production of hormone by thyroid, but rather due to release of pre-formed hormone as seen in thyroiditis, radio-iodine destruction or production of hormone from other sites like Struma Ovarii
  • In Graves’ disease, the iodine scan would show diffusely increased uptake.
  • In papillary cancer of thyroid, the patient would usually be euthyroid.
  • In Plummer’s disease, there would be a single nodule with increased uptake.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presented in surgery OPD with complain of dragging pain in lower limb especially after prolonged standing. On examination dilated veins were found without pigmentation, skin changes or ulceration. What is the CEAP classification for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

C2s
 

  • Visible varicose vein is classified as C2 which is further subdivided into C2a (asymptomatic) and C2s (symptomatic).
  • Since this patient is symptomatic, he will be classified as C2s.

questions.text: What is the ideal age of cleft palate reconstruction for residual alveolar cleft?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

10 years

  • Alveolar cleft is managed before than age of eruption of canine (around 8-10 years).
  • Cleft lip - 3-6 months
  • Cleft palate- 1 year
  • Secondary repair- 4-6 years
  • Orthognathic repair – 14-16 years

choices.text: 3rd generation cephalosporin with Anti TNF α agents
Total proctocolectomy and Ileal pouch anastomosis
Total colectomy and Brooke’s ileostomy
Proximal defunctioning Ileostomy

questions.text: A known cased of ulcerative colitis presented with pain abdomen, bloody diarrhoea, and fever. His TLC was 16,000. His abdominal X-ray is shown below. He was managed with antibiotics, mesalamine and IV corticosteroids but there was no response after 4-5 days. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

Total colectomy and Brooke’s ileostomy
 

  • This is Toxic megacolon of UC which is managed by total colectomy and Brooke’s ileostomy (this is best emergency surgery for UC)
  • Best elective surgery for UC is total proctocolectomy and Ileal pouch anal anastomosis.
  • Third generation cephalosporin with anti-TNF agent can be given for severe UC, but not with toxic megacolon.
  • Proximal defunctioning ileostomy has no role in its management.

questions.text: In a patient with breast cancer, IHC is ordered. For what value of Her 2 neu expression would FISH be done?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 

2+

  • If IHC for Her 2 neu is 0 or 1+, it is considered negative
  • IHC of 2+ is considered equivocal for which FISH is done
  • 3+ is considered positive

choices.text: For surgeries of the thyroid, bipolar cautery is preferred over monopolar cautery
In monopolar cautery, cutting is represented by blue colour and coagulation is represented by yellow colour.
In coagulation mode, cautery is on 6% of the time and off 94% of the time.
Ligasure can seal up to 7 mm.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about electrocautery is false?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

In monopolar cautery, cutting is represented by blue colour and coagulation is represented by yellow colour

  • For surgeries of the thyroid, bipolar cautery is preferred over monopolar cautery to prevent nerve damage
  • In monopolar cautery, cutting is represented by yellow colour and coagulation is represented by blue colour
  • In coagulation mode, cautery is on 6% of the time and off 94% of the time
  • Ligasure can seal up to 7 mm

questions.text: Which of the following is not a perineal repair for rectal prolapse?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The Ripstein repair is not a perineal repair for rectal prolapse; it is an abdominal (laparoscopic or open) rectopexy procedure. In the Ripstein procedure, the rectum is mobilized and then secured to the sacrum using a synthetic mesh or fascia strip that wraps partially or completely around the rectum to prevent it from descending. All abdominal rectopexy procedures are performed via an incision in the abdomen, differentiating them from perineal approaches which are performed through the anus.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the qSOFA score?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pulse rate (or Heart Rate) is not a component of the quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (qSOFA) score. The qSOFA score is a rapid bedside tool used to identify patients with suspected infection who are at risk for a poor outcome (sepsis). It is specifically designed to be simple and easily measurable. The score consists of only three criteria, none of which include the pulse rate.

choices.text: Single cycle of intravesical mitomycin C

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient comes to the outpatient department with complains of blood in urine. On cystoscopy, a 1x1 cm bladder mass was seen. So a TURBT was done which showed T1 transitional cell carcinoma. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 

Intravesical BCG

  • For T1 tumours, intravesical BCG is given.
  • For non-invasive papillary tumours, a single cycle of intravesical mitomycin C is given.
  • Partial cystectomy is done for T2 tumours involving the dome of the bladder.
  • If ureteric orifices are involved or there is hydronephrosis, radical cystectomy is done.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents to you with features of schizophrenia. You start her on haloperidol. Which of the following is the mechanism of intracellular signaling of the receptor this drug acts on?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 

¯ cAMP

 

  • Haloperidol is a typical anti-psychotic medication which acts by inhibiting D2 receptors. D2 receptors act via Gi protein to decrease intracellular cAMP levels.
  • Hormones like TSH, LH and FSH act via Gs protein to increase intracellular cAMP levels.
  • Hormones like GnRH, V1 receptor and a1 receptor act via Gq protein to increase the levels of intracellular calcium.
  • Prolactin, insulin, growth hormone and interleukins act via receptor tyrosine kinase.
